To talk about the complicated relationship between the United States and Pakistan, we turn to Steve Coll, who writes about the war on terror for the New Yorker magazine.
Coll says during today's meeting President Bush is likely to press for Pakistan to take action against the powerful Taliban presence on its border with Afghanistan.

In the Pakistani city of Quetta, it is generally believed that Taliban leadership have taken refuge and that they actually run a sort of leadership group that's commonly called the Quetta shura or the Taliban shura.
The fact that those Afghan leaders are free is I think a concern both to the United States and its allies at - in NATO who are on the ground in southern Afghanistan fighting the Taliban.
They'd like to see these people arrested.
They'd like to see the networks and safe houses that they rely upon broken up.
So is this likely to top the agenda, this meeting between President Bush and President Musharraf?
Yes.

And at the same time United States remains very interested in the desultory hunt for Osama bin Laden and Ayman al-Zawahiri, the two exiled leaders of al-Qaida who are thought to be hiding someplace in the borderlands between Pakistan and Afghanistan.
The president has said recently that he'd like to flood the zone and to step up the pace of that surge.
And it really can't be done without Pakistani cooperation.
What can the president do to ensure that cooperation?

Well, the Pakistanis are well-accustomed to this American agenda and have so far been judged, at least by the United States and its European allies, cooperative on al-Qaida and less cooperative on the Taliban, which has been a source of Pakistani statecraft and strategy in Afghanistan dating back almost a decade now.
And there are elements of the Pakistan military who continue to believe that the Taliban is a useful instrument of Pakistani foreign policy in the region.
Well, the Bush administration does consider Pakistan to be an important ally in its war on terror, but there are a lot of pressures on this alliance, from both sides.
There are, and from the Pakistani point of view, one big question is trust.
Do they really believe that the United States is going to be partner of the Pakistani army and of Pakistan in the long run?
Or is this a short-term alliance, they ask.
What are some of the domestic/political pressures on President Musharraf?
Well, Musharraf has tried to manage politics in Pakistan from the top down.
And it's been a very difficult enterprise, and he hasn't succeeded altogether.

He faces opposition both from the sort of secular left, and at the same time he faces pressure from the religious right, which judges him to be a puppet of American foreign policy in the country and which has increasingly been uncooperative on domestic issues.
Ultimately, what do you expect is going to come out this meeting then?
Well, I think the Bush administration is anxious to persuade Musharraf that they really are going to be his partner.

President Bush visited Pakistan earlier this year and the meeting was judged to be unsuccessful, if not outright disastrous, because they appeared together in public and the president was judged to be sort of lecturing or hectoring Musharraf.
Since then, the Americans have gone out of their way to try to emphasize their faith in Musharraf.
The vice president went on television and spoke unequivocally about Musharraf's sort of credentials as a staunch ally.
And I'm sure the president will use this meeting to try to rebuild some of the trust that broke down earlier in the year.
It's a real sort of high wire act, it sounds like.
It is.
Yeah, a lot of atmospherics and a little bit of substance.
